Chapter 7 of Theorem Proving in Lean
explains how to define Peano natural numbers and addition, and to inductively prove the commutative law of addition and related lemmas.

https://leanprover.github.io/theorem_proving_in_lean4/inductive_types.html#defining-the-natural-numbers

inductive MyNat where
  | zero : MyNat
  | succ : MyNat → MyNat

namespace MyNat

def add : MyNat → MyNat → MyNat
  | a, zero => a
  | a, succ b => succ (add a b)

infixl:65 " + " => add

-- Theorem 1: a + 0 = a
theorem add_zero (a : MyNat) : a + zero = a := by
  rfl

-- Theorem 2: 0 + a = a
theorem zero_add (a : MyNat) : zero + a = a := by
  induction a with
  | zero => rfl
  | succ a ih =>
    rw [add, ih]

-- Theorem 3: a + b.succ = (a + b).succ
theorem add_succ (a b : MyNat) : a + succ b = succ (a + b) := by
  rfl

-- Theorem 4: a.succ + b = (a + b).succ
theorem succ_add (a b : MyNat) : succ a + b = succ (a + b) := by
  induction b with
  | zero => rfl
  | succ b ih =>
    rw [add, add, ih]

-- Theorem 5: a + b = b + a
theorem add_comm (a b : MyNat) : a + b = b + a := by
  induction b with
  | zero =>
    rw [add_zero, zero_add]
  | succ b ih =>
    rw [add_succ, succ_add, ih]

end MyNat

I also read that the definition of natural numbers and addition written here is one of many equivalent definitions. Although this affects Lean's understanding of what are definitionally equal, for humans these different definitions mean the same thing.

I've always kept this in mind, but never tried it successfully, so today I decided to define another addition, add2, as follows. It turns a + b.succ into a.succ + b instead of (a + b).succ.

As far as I can tell, this function is no longer structural recursion, but well-found recursion, and Lean automatically proves that this recursion terminates in finite time for me, so this function is more complicated than it looks.

I tried for a while, and I couldn't figure out how to prove any properties of this thing, I couldn't prove that it was commutative, associative, or equivalent to regular addition.

There must be a way to prove these properties, since they are true propositions, right? But what is the proof? Why are these induction proofs more complicated than they seem?

#print Nat

-- The ordinary definition of add
def add1 : Nat → Nat → Nat
  | a, .zero => a
  | a, .succ b => (add1 a b).succ

-- A new definition of add
def add2 : Nat → Nat → Nat
  | a, .zero => a
  | a, .succ b => add2 a.succ b

infixl:65 " +₁ " => add1  -- left-associative
infixl:65 " +₂ " => add2  -- left-associative

#eval 100 +₁ 50
#eval 100 +₂ 50

theorem add1_eq_add2 (a b : Nat) : a +₁ b = a +₂ b := by
  sorry

This still seems to be structurally recursive (on parameter b), though I am not sure how much Lean tries to "see" that.

Proving that the new function has the same properties as the standard one should be possible, but since recursive calls also change parameter a, you will probably have to go for recursive hypotheses that quantify universally on a. And yes, this makes the proofs more complicated.

I think this complexity is a testament to how special these inductive proofs in Chapter 7 are. Even a slight change in the definition makes the previous successful experience no longer applicable (which is similar to a lot of pure math things, I guess...)
Fortunately, most proofs don't require touching this low-level stuff.

fwiw:

theorem add_succ2 : (a b : Nat) → add2 a.succ b = (add2 a b).succ
 | _, 0 => rfl
 | a, b+1 => add_succ2 a.succ b

theorem add1_eq_add2 : (a b : Nat) → a +₁ b = a +₂ b
  | _, 0 => rfl
  | a, b+1 => by
    have ih := add1_eq_add2 a b
    simp only [add1, add2, add_succ2, ih]

I agree that these finer details can be tricky, I think that's a big part of what motivates the lean/mathlib design pattern of hiding these kinds of definitional issues behind an "api" that largely hides them from consumers.

As far as I can tell, this function is no longer structural recursion, but well-found recursion

Looking at #print add2, it seems like structural recursion to me.

For fun, here's a tactic version of Chris's proofs.

theorem add_succ2 (a b : Nat) : add2 a.succ b = (add2 a b).succ := by
  induction b generalizing a with
  | zero => rfl
  | succ b' ih => rw [add2, add2, ih]

theorem add1_eq_add2 (a b : Nat) : add1 a b = add2 a b := by
  induction b with
  | zero => rfl
  | succ b' ih => rw [add1, ih, add2, add_succ2]
I'm glad this proof doesn't seem very long. Thank you!!
Deming Xu has marked this topic as resolved.

I figured out the whole equivalent forms of the five theorems I listed...

Imitating what you did in the add_succ2, it turns out that most patterns can be copied. We can still split cases on b into .zero and .succ b.
When our goal is
myself a b.succ, (where myself is the theorem name),
we just need to assume the induction hypothesis
have ih := myself a.succ b
instead of
have ih := myself a b in the original +₁
in these induction proofs. Pretty much just like the definition of add2 itself.
add2 a b.succ := add2 a.succ b

That's also why we need the induction b generalizing a in tactic mode, because we need to change the a to a.succ in ih.

The only significant difference is that, theorem2 now seems to depend on theorem3 somehow, so I swapped theorems 3, 4 and 1, 2.

#print Nat

-- The ordinary definition of add
def add1 : Nat → Nat → Nat
  | a, .zero => a
  | a, .succ b => (add1 a b).succ

-- A new definition of add
def add2 : Nat → Nat → Nat
  | a, .zero => a
  | a, .succ b => add2 a.succ b

infixl:65 " +₁ " => add1
infixl:65 " +₂ " => add2

#eval 100 +₁ 50
#eval 100 +₂ 50



-- Theorem3: a.succ + b = (a + b).succ
theorem add_succ2 : (a b : Nat) → a +₂ b.succ = (a +₂ b).succ
  | a, 0 => rfl
  | a, .succ b => by
    have ih := add_succ2 a.succ b
    dsimp only [add2] at *
    exact ih

-- Theorem4: a + b.succ = (a + b).succ
theorem succ_add2 : (a b : Nat) → a.succ +₂ b = (a +₂ b).succ
  | a, 0 => rfl
  | a, .succ b => by
    have ih := succ_add2 a.succ b
    dsimp only [add2] at *
    exact ih

-- Theorem1: a + 0 = a
theorem add_zero2 : (a : Nat) → a +₂ 0 = a := fun a => rfl

-- Theorem2: 0 + a = a
-- This one somehow breaks the symmetry of the two definitions
-- It depends on theorem3.
theorem zero_add2 : (a : Nat) → 0 +₂ a = a
  | Nat.zero => rfl
  | Nat.succ a => by
    have ih := zero_add2 a
    rw [add_succ2, ih]



-- Theorem5: a + b = b + a
theorem add_comm2 : (a b : Nat) → a +₂ b = b +₂ a
  | a, 0 => by rw [add_zero2, zero_add2]
  | a, .succ b => by
    have ih := add_comm2 a.succ b
    dsimp only [add2] at *
    exact ih

-- Theorem6: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)
theorem add_assoc2 : (a b c : Nat) → (a +₂ b) +₂ c = a +₂ (b +₂ c)
  | a, b, 0 => rfl
  | a, b, .succ c => by
    have ih := add_assoc2 a b c
    -- ⊢ a +₂ b +₂ c.succ = a +₂ (b +₂ c.succ)
    -- just bubble up the two succ to the outermost level
    rw [add_succ2, add_succ2, add_succ2, ih]

-- Theorem7: +₁ = +₂
theorem add1_eq_add2 : (a b : Nat) → a +₁ b = a +₂ b
  | _, 0 => rfl
  | a, .succ b => by
    have ih := add1_eq_add2 a b
    rw [add1, add2, succ_add2, ih]

Here is how to turn Lean turned add2 into an explicit structural recursion.

-- A new definition of add
def add2 : Nat → Nat → Nat
  | a, .zero => a
  | a, .succ b => add2 a.succ b

def add3 : Nat → Nat → Nat :=
  let rec row : (b : Nat) → ((a : Nat) → Nat)
  /-
  Imagine there is an infinitely large "multiplication table"
  containing all the "column_number + row_number" values. (ie "a + b")
  Here each `row b` defines a single row in the table.
  The row is of type: `column_number : Nat -> Nat`.
  We run a "loop" to construct the table row by row.
  -/
    | 0 => (fun a => a)
    | .succ b => (fun a => (row b) a.succ) -- column_number + 1 at the last row
  fun a b => (row b) a
